content.question: Which of the following best explains why the polymerase from the species T. aquaticus is often used for <math alttext="P C R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>PCR</mtext></mrow></math>?

choices.label: T. aquaticus polymerase has an optimal temperature of <math alttext="68 degrees Celsius " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>68</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
T. aquaticus polymerase does not denature at high temperatures.
T. aquaticus polymerase can be used more than once without degrading.

T. aquaticus polymerase adds nucleotides to both the <math alttext="3 prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>′</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> and <math alttext="5 prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>′</mo></mrow></math> ends of <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: T. aquaticus polymerase does not denature at high temperatures.
